column1: Their knowledge of society had taught these men that there was a huge audience that wanted to laugh and that comedians had to strain every nerve and to try every joke in order to release that laughter.

column1: Vincent strained every nerve to turn himself into a draughtsman acceptable to the illustrated papers, and the strain showed.

column1: Confronted by the imminent threat of Nazi invasion, and convinced that only by straining every nerve could Britain avoid the fate of France, millions of people came, perhaps for the first time, to perceive the nation not as something to which they were admitted by the grace of kings, but as their own authentic community.

column1: Every nerve had been strained in the effort to prompt Lou's memory but what she had learned could do little to prove Barney's innocence.
